list_definition.definition: a chief product of trade or industry.
a chief or main item (of diet etc).
a U-shaped piece of wire that is driven through sheets of paper etc to fasten them together.
to fasten or attach (paper etc) with staples

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She stapled the pages of the report together.

list_ex_of_english: However, why should they not pay, if the ordinary people pay value added tax on bread, milk and other staples?
Will the record say how many staples were missing?
By the mid 1920s, display advertisements for consumer durables, leisure activities and homes outstripped those for traditional staples such as clothing or foodstuffs.
The recent dramatic price increases, particularly for rice, maize and other staples, are of course another major reason why many people do not have enough food.
During the previous century, trade had increased dramatically as new products - sugar, tobacco and cotton - not produced in the importing region became international staples.
There are three acknowledged staples of life—food, clothing and housing.
To a large extent, the effects of the decline of the great export staples spread throughout the local economies of the outer regions.
However, the existence of local markets for food encouraged farmers to produce these staples for sale in addition to home consumption.
